section.title: creating records
section.para: Use insertinsert(mysql) to enter data into the table. The screenshot shows an insert statement that inserts values depending on the position of the data in the statement.
section.screen: mysql> insert into country values ('BE','Belgium','11000000','Brussels'); Query OK, 1 row affected (0.03 sec)
section.para: Some administrators prefer to use uppercase for sqlSQL keywords. The mysql client accepts both.
section.screen: mysql> INSERT INTO country VALUES ('FR','France','65000000','Paris'); Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

section.title: viewing all records
section.para: And finally an example of a simple selectselect(mysql) query to look at the contents of a table.

section.title: updating records
section.para: Consider the following insert statement. The capital of Spain is not Barcelona, it is Madrid.
section.screen: mysql> INSERT INTO country VALUES ('ES','Spain','46000000','Barcelona'); Query OK, 1 row affected (0.01 sec)
section.para: Using an updateupdate(mysql) statement, the record can be updated.

section.title: viewing selected records
section.para: Using a where clause in a selectselect(mysql) statement, you can specify which record(s) you want to see.

section.title: deleting records
section.para: You can use the deletedelete(mysql) to permanently remove a record from a table.
